path_1.title: Reign of Fire (2002)
path_1.feeling: Cool premise, but it left me mostly lukewarm.

path_1.title: Missing, The (2003)
path_1.feeling: Quietly affecting, but it didn’t fully pull me in.

path_1.title: Corpse Bride (2005)
path_1.feeling: Lovely gothic charm and visuals, even if the emotion is lighter.

path_1.title: Hocus Pocus (1993)
path_1.feeling: Cute seasonal fun, but it’s more camp than magic for me.

path_1.title: 50 First Dates (2004)
path_1.feeling: Sweet idea, but the humor and schmaltz wore thin.

path_1.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_1.feeling: Deeply moving and humane, it really got under my skin.

path_1.title: Bridge, The (2006)
path_1.feeling: Important subject, engaging but a bit dry.

path_1.title: I'm Not There (2007)
path_1.feeling: Inventive and mesmerizing in parts, but uneven overall.

path_1.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_1.feeling: Lush, operatic gothic romance that I happily sank into.

path_1.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_1.feeling: Creepy and iconic, though its pacing tested me.

path_1.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_1.feeling: Irresistible old-school comfort that still works for me.

path_1.title: Memento (2000)
path_1.feeling: Smart, twisty storytelling that stays fun to untangle.

path_1.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_1.feeling: Earnest but syrupy

path_1.title: Sleepers (1996)
path_1.feeling: Grim and gripping, with performances that carry it.

path_1.title: True Grit (2010)
path_1.feeling: Lean, beautifully crafted Coens tale that stuck with me.

path_1.title: Music and Lyrics (2007)
path_1.feeling: Light, catchy fluff—pleasant but disposable.

path_1.title: Stakeout (1987)
path_1.feeling: Entertaining enough, but nothing really lingers.

path_1.title: Public Enemies (2009)
path_1.feeling: Handsome and cool, yet emotionally distant.

path_1.title: Knocked Up (2007)
path_1.feeling: Funny in spots, but the balance of crude and sweet is uneven.

path_1.title: Outbreak (1995)
path_1.feeling: Solid ’90s thriller vibes, for better and worse.

path_1.title: End of the Affair, The (1999)
path_1.feeling: Sumptuous and melancholy—I liked the ache more than the plot.

path_1.title: Wayne's World (1992)
path_1.feeling: Goofy and quotable, though not really my sweet spot.

path_1.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_1.feeling: Cringe-y fun with enough laughs to work.

path_1.title: Little Mermaid, The (1989)
path_1.feeling: Classic Disney magic—songs and nostalgia hit nicely.

path_1.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
path_1.feeling: Witty, warm, and honest—one of the few rom-coms that really lands.

path_1.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_1.feeling: Still unsettling, though its slow burn keeps me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Holiday, The (2006)
path_1.feeling: Cozy and glossy, but too sugary for my taste.

path_1.title: Italian Job, The (2003)
path_1.feeling: Snappy heist fun that goes down easy and fades fast.

path_1.title: Cruel Intentions (1999)
path_1.feeling: Glossy, wicked fun with just enough bite.

path_1.title: Born on the Fourth of July (1989)
path_1.feeling: Powerful and earnest, if a bit heavy-handed.

path_2.title: Reign of Fire (2002)
path_2.feeling: Pulpy post-apocalyptic dragon yarn—some scale, little soul.

path_2.feeling: Quiet, intergenerational search drama that sounds sincere but slight.

path_2.title: Corpse Bride (2005)
path_2.feeling: Gothic, bittersweet fable with lovely design and gentle melancholy.

path_2.title: Hocus Pocus (1993)
path_2.feeling: Light, campy Halloween fluff—fun in spurts, rarely magical.

path_2.title: 50 First Dates (2004)
path_2.feeling: High-concept romcom with some sweetness, plenty of broad shtick.

path_2.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, humane prison fable that hit my sentimental side.

path_2.title: Bridge, The (2006)
path_2.feeling: Human, hopeful look at coexistence built on fragile ground.

path_2.title: I'm Not There (2007)
path_2.feeling: Playfully fragmented, idea-rich portrait—intriguing more than moving.

path_2.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Lush, operatic gothic romance whose style seduces more than its scares.

path_2.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_2.feeling: Prickly, escalating dread with a cool, uncanny edge.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)

path_2.title: Memento (2000)

path_2.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)

path_2.title: Sleepers (1996)
path_2.feeling: Grim, cathartic melodrama powered by its ensemble.

path_2.title: True Grit (2010)

path_2.title: Music and Lyrics (2007)
path_2.feeling: Breezy, tuneful fluff with just enough charm to pass.

path_2.title: Stakeout (1987)
path_2.feeling: Light, watchable cop-romp with modest laughs and stakes.

path_2.title: Public Enemies (2009)
path_2.feeling: Cool, meticulous crime saga that kept me at a distance.

path_2.title: Knocked Up (2007)
path_2.feeling: Shaggy, likable hangout comedy with some heart and some bloat.

path_2.feeling: Serviceable epidemic thriller—urgent, tidy, not especially deep.

path_2.title: End of the Affair, The (1999)
path_2.feeling: Moody, adult romantic torment with moral currents I appreciate.

path_2.feeling: Goofy, quotable lark that amuses more than it endears.

path_2.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_2.feeling: Anxious, well-oiled cringe machine—funny in waves.

path_2.title: Little Mermaid, The (1989)
path_2.feeling: Sweeping, song-rich fairy tale that still charms.

path_2.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)
path_2.feeling: Witty, tender, and wise about love—comfort food done right.

path_2.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_2.feeling: Slow-burn natural-menace nightmare—icy and effective.

path_2.title: Holiday, The (2006)
path_2.feeling: Cozy, glossy escapism with predictable but pleasant rhythms.

path_2.title: Italian Job, The (2003)
path_2.feeling: Slick, lightweight caper with brisk gears and little residue.

path_2.title: Cruel Intentions (1999)
path_2.feeling: Sleek, nasty teen melodrama—entertaining if a bit hollow.

path_2.title: Born on the Fourth of July (1989)
path_2.feeling: Sober, impassioned character study with bruising conviction.

path_2.feeling: Sparse, intergenerational search that felt gentle but slight.

path_2.title: Corpse Bride (2005)

path_2.title: I'm Not There (2007)
path_2.feeling: Playful, prismatic portrait—intriguing more than deeply affecting.

path_2.feeling: Gothic and operatic—lushly mounted, if overheated.

path_2.feeling: Icy, creeping dread that impresses more than it moves.

path_2.title: Outbreak (1995)

path_2.title: Wayne's World (1992)
path_2.feeling: Slack, goofy charm

path_2.feeling: Cringe-forward farce that works in fits and starts.

path_2.title: When Harry Met Sally... (1989)

path_2.title: Little Mermaid, The (1989)

path_2.feeling: Cold, creeping menace executed with elegant control.

path_2.title: Holiday, The (2006)

path_2.title: Reign of Fire (2002)

path_2.title: Corpse Bride (2005)

path_2.title: Hocus Pocus (1993)

path_2.title: 50 First Dates (2004)

path_2.title: Green Mile, The (1999)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, humane prison fable that hit my sentimental side, even with the supernatural.

path_2.title: Bridge, The (2006)
path_2.feeling: Thoughtful, hopeful portrait of fragile coexistence that moved me more in moments than as a whole.

path_2.title: I'm Not There (2007)
path_2.feeling: Playful, shape-shifting portrait—intriguing and artful, if emotionally cool.

path_2.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Lush, operatic gothic romance whose swoon sometimes eclipses its heart, but I enjoyed the mood.

path_2.title: Birds, The (1963)
path_2.feeling: Cold, unnerving menace that accumulates into a haunting, unsettling parable.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Warm, old-fashioned musical comfort that still charms me.

path_2.title: Memento (2000)
path_2.feeling: Ingenious, propulsive puzzle anchored by a surprisingly human ache.

path_2.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, weepy romance that left me mostly unmoved.

path_2.title: Sleepers (1996)
path_2.feeling: Strong performances and grim subject matter—absorbing if somewhat heavy-handed.

path_2.title: True Grit (2010)

path_2.title: Music and Lyrics (2007)
path_2.feeling: Pleasant, lightly charming confection with a sweet center but little lasting impact.

path_2.title: Stakeout (1987)
path_2.feeling: Easygoing stakeout caper with some chemistry—enjoyable but disposable.

path_2.title: Public Enemies (2009)
path_2.feeling: Cool, handsome crime saga whose chill kept me a step removed, but I was engaged.

path_2.title: Knocked Up (2007)
path_2.feeling: Raunchy-meets-tender blend that works better for its messy human warmth than its gags.

path_2.title: Outbreak (1995)
path_2.feeling: Competent pandemic thriller that kept me hooked if not deeply invested.

path_2.title: End of the Affair, The (1999)
path_2.feeling: Moody, aching love story that stirred me in stretches even as the melodrama swelled.

path_2.title: Wayne's World (1992)
path_2.feeling: Goofy, quotable hangout comedy—fun in the moment, slight afterward.

path_2.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_2.feeling: Cringe-y, well-oiled farce that amused me without winning my heart.

path_2.title: Little Mermaid, The (1989)
path_2.feeling: Buoyant, tuneful fairy tale with real charm, even if it's lighter than my usual fare.

path_2.feeling: Witty, warm, and keenly observed—romance that feels lived-in and true.

path_2.feeling: A chilly, slow-burn nightmare whose final images stick.

path_2.title: Holiday, The (2006)

path_2.title: Italian Job, The (2003)

path_2.title: Cruel Intentions (1999)
path_2.feeling: Slick, mean-spirited melodrama that intrigued me without giving me much to feel.

path_2.title: Born on the Fourth of July (1989)

path_3.title: Reign of Fire (2002)

path_3.feeling: Earnest, timeless uplift that still warms me.

path_3.feeling: Dark, morally weighty revenge tale that holds me.

path_3.feeling: Goofy, quotable fun that amuses without really landing emotionally.

path_3.feeling: Sweeping songs and fairy-tale heart that still charms me.

path_3.feeling: Glossy, mean-spirited games I’d find intriguing but shallow.

path_3.feeling: A fragile, earnest look at coexistence I’d appreciate for its human stakes more than its craft.

path_3.feeling: Elegant, escalating dread I’d appreciate for its chilly craft and tension.

path_3.title: Sleepers (1996)

path_3.title: True Grit (2010)

path_3.title: End of the Affair, The (1999)
path_3.feeling: A jealous, aching period romance I’d find thoughtful if a bit reserved.

path_3.title: Wayne's World (1992)
path_3.feeling: Goofy, quotable hangout energy that amuses me more than it moves me.

path_3.title: Meet the Parents (2000)
path_3.feeling: Cringe-fueled comedy of errors that’s funny enough but lightweight for me.

path_3.feeling: Lively, melodic Disney romance that charms me with its songs and heart.

path_3.title: Holiday, The (2006)
